messages: a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (15:44): ok kids
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (15:44): check THIS out
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (15:45): http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20060730/ap_on_sc/lake_erie_mirage
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (15:45): apparently thermal ducting works all the way into light frequencies.
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (15:45): it works quite nicely at 2.4 :P
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (15:47): http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20060730/ap_on_sc/lake_erie_mirage
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (15:47): visual thermal ducting
776833c15e61c1feac12e570742b7258 (15:48): interesting, or it could be some vlle canadian trick!
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (15:49): all the stuff I read for ham radio says it simply won't happen at microwave frequencies.  And these guys are saying it can work all the way into light.
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (15:49): that fully explains my 2.4 skip
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (15:49): well "skip"
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (15:49): as its not really skip
776833c15e61c1feac12e570742b7258 (15:52): you have seen skip at 2.4g ?
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (15:53): I've seen ssids as far as 250 miles away
776833c15e61c1feac12e570742b7258 (15:53): that's interesting,
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (15:53): I throw the hpol omni into "snooper" mode here, and I hear some craaaaazy stuff sometimes
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (15:54): I've heard all around San Antonio, Lake Conroe, Downtown Houston, north Ft Worth, Canton, Tyler....  just depends on whats 'good'
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (15:54): rarely hear much east of me, except some folks that are legitimately LOS, barely.
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (15:54): and they're vpol, we rarely hear it anymore.
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (15:54): theres really nothing east of me for a loooong way.
776833c15e61c1feac12e570742b7258 (15:55): I wouldn't expect 'mirage' thermal layers to do microwave, but then again, if they'll do optical, , , then why not?
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (15:55): just depends on the layer width, I'd guess.
776833c15e61c1feac12e570742b7258 (15:55): makes my head hurt
776833c15e61c1feac12e570742b7258 (15:55): have you slept yet?
addad51e4f5f7e71fec293b40534a2f8 (15:57): i thought ISM was line of sight
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (15:57): nah, I gotta be up around 9...  I'll take a nap sometime tomorrow afternoon
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (15:57): rr--: it is... but obviously LOS can bend quite a bit
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (15:57): with thermal ducting
776833c15e61c1feac12e570742b7258 (15:59): yeah, so it seems, it makes sense I guess, I just never thought of it before.
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (16:00): I see a lot less of it with downtilted sectors
776833c15e61c1feac12e570742b7258 (16:00): I do know that the navy managed to put up a microwave link from GB to Turkey without a relay station for a few days back in the 70s, that's not los.
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (16:00): the 13 dbi omni seems to be tuned a hairbit over the horizon
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (16:00): 2 degrees below the horizon generally sucks ;P
addad51e4f5f7e71fec293b40534a2f8 (16:00): and even with 'ducting', whatever that is, i would have thought distance (path loss) would effectively kill whatever signal managed to get 'ducted'
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (16:00): too much gain for the altitude I guess
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (16:01): rr--: you can get up to +60 db of gain from ducting
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (16:01): I've had the noise floor here jump into the low 80s before
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (16:01): and theres nothing around here...  *nothing* nearby
776833c15e61c1feac12e570742b7258 (16:03): sssh, it's hparker
addad51e4f5f7e71fec293b40534a2f8 (16:05): too much voodoo in this field, it seems
addad51e4f5f7e71fec293b40534a2f8 (16:07): if it's not no signal or multipath it's ducted signal from god knows where
776833c15e61c1feac12e570742b7258 (16:08): rr--, it's only voodoo if you don't understand it, so it's voodoo to me.
776833c15e61c1feac12e570742b7258 (16:08): hparker gets it though.
addad51e4f5f7e71fec293b40534a2f8 (16:09): maybe it's the aliens playing with the humans
776833c15e61c1feac12e570742b7258 (16:09): hey, hparker, can you 'skip' microwaves off of thermal ducts?
60ef8eb03f7889973380e99d0248b673 (16:11): hrrr.... Not sure on that one
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (16:22): http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TV-FM_DX
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (16:22): it works...

a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (16:23): In 1957, the world record for TV DX was extended to 10,800 miles (17,400 km) with the reception of England's BBC channel 1 in various parts of Australia. Most notably, George Palmer in Melbourne, Victoria, received viewable pictures from the BBC London channel B1 station. This BBC F2 reception was recorded on movie film.
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (16:23): holy shit!
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (16:24): http://www.dxinfocentre.com/tropo.html
addad51e4f5f7e71fec293b40534a2f8 (16:27): not predictably or reliably, i assume
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (16:28): not at all
addad51e4f5f7e71fec293b40534a2f8 (16:29): only when the planets/heavens are aligned in some way or some such

a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (16:30): when I had my TV antenna at 45 ft, with the amplifier and good coax (all two weeks before a lightning strike ate it) I could hear the florida panhandle almost every night
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (16:30): and baton rouge was loud and clear
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (16:30): but it required lots of aiming
addad51e4f5f7e71fec293b40534a2f8 (16:30): did ubiquiti answer the e-mail asking what min. separation they recommend between 900 mhz and 2.4 ghz
addad51e4f5f7e71fec293b40534a2f8 (16:32): let alone give a formula for computing it
